channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Saudi Arabia Warns of Economic Fallout if Congress Passes 9/11 Bill
item.media:description: President Obama at a Sept. 11 ceremony in 2015. The Obama administration argues that the bill would put Americans at legal risk overseas.
item.description: The kingdom has bristled over a bill that would allow its government to be held responsible in American courts for any role in the Sept. 11 attacks.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: Fight to Impeach Brazil’s Leader Tears at Fabric of Daily Life
item.media:description: Brazil’s attorney general, José Eduardo Cardozo, top left, presented the defense of President Dilma Rousseff on Friday in Brasilia as opposition lawmakers held signs urging impeachment.
item.description: Brazilian politics is a blood sport in the best of times, but the battle over whether to impeach President Dilma Rousseff is inflaming passions as never before.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Files Suggest Honduran Police Leaders Ordered Killing of Antidrug Officials
item.media:description: Military police officers stood guard after the former police headquarters in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, were raided on April 4.
item.description: New documents paint a chilling portrait of impunity at the very top of Honduras’s police hierarchy: the unchallenged power to carry out assassinations.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN and ALBERTO ARCE

item.title: Egyptians Denounce President Sisi in Biggest Rally in 2 Years
item.description: The demonstration was the largest in two years and the most significant challenge by protesters forced into the shadows by a violent state crackdown.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Families of Americans Held by Allies Say U.S. Is Keeping Its Gloves On
item.media:description: The White House was successful in pressuring the Egyptian government to release Mohamed Soltan, an American citizen who carried out a 16-month hunger strike.
item.description: Relatives have complained of a lack of high-level attention from American officials — stemming, they fear, from reluctance to confront Egypt and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Iraq in Political Limbo After Stalled Reform Attempts
item.media:description: The Iraqi Parliament speaker Salim al-Jabouri, center, during a news conference in Baghdad on Wednesday. Lawmakers did not reach a quorum for a vote to oust him on Saturday.
item.description: Failed attempts to oust the speaker of parliament and a fresh ultimatum from an influential Shiite cleric have left Iraq in a state of political limbo. Backroom negotiations continued late into the night Saturday between Iraq's powerful political blocs after lawmakers attempting to oust speaker Selim al-Jabouri failed to maintain quorum.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russian Forces Remain Heavily Involved in Syria, Despite Appearances
item.media:description: A Syrian man carried a carpet along a street in Palmyra, a town that Russian forces helped Syria retake from Islamic State fighters.
item.description: Russian attack helicopters replaced jets as Russia operates a secretive war in its effort to influence the political outcome in Syria.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Angela Merkel Draws Criticism for Allowing Turkey’s Case Against Comic
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann at an awards ceremony in Düsseldorf, Germany, in January. The German comedian faces a lawsuit over his lampooning of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey.
item.media:credit: Rolf Vennenbernd/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Chancellor Merkel’s move to permit a court case against the comic, Jan Böhmermann, made clear that she does not want to antagonize President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, whom he lampooned.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: E.U. Offers to Loosen Restrictions on Iran Air
item.media:description: An Iran Air plane in France in 2010. The airline has been banned from European air space for five years.
item.description: Europe sharply curtailed access to its airspace for Iran’s aging airline fleet five years ago because of airworthiness concerns.
item.dc:creator: NICOLA CLARK

item.title: More Than 40 in Japan Are Confirmed Dead in Earthquakes
item.media:description: A main street was covered with the debris of a newly collapsed house after a second earthquake hit southwestern Japan, in Mashiki, Kumamoto Prefecture, on Saturday.
item.description: Aftershocks were continuing on the island of Kyushu, and a warning that strong quakes were possible for several more days was issued.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Farmers in Arid India Share Camps With Their Cattle
item.media:description: A cattle camp in Latur, India, where farmers are able to get food and water for their cattle.
item.media:credit: Anshuman Poyrekar/Hindustan Times, via Getty Images
item.description: In a nation where cows are both sacred and essential, camps have been set up to preserve them in a drought. But instead of dropping them off, the owners are staying.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Taliban Attack Kunduz City, Alarming Afghans
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel searched commuters at a checkpoint in Kunduz Province on Friday.
item.description: Officials said they ended the assault on the city, but fear remained that lack of unity among the Army and the police could weaken security.
item.dc:creator: NAJIM RAHIM and MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Bangladeshi Editor, 81, Is Accused in Plot to Kill Leader’s Son
item.media:description: Bangladeshi security officers escort Shafik Rehman, 81, at a court after his arrest on Saturday in Dhaka.
item.description: The arrest of the editor, Shafik Rehman, is the latest in a string of criminal proceedings against journalists in Bangladesh.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR and NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Dilma Rousseff’s Former Supporters in Brazil Express Disillusionment
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff of Brazil.
item.description: As the president faces a possible impeachment, working-class people who brought her party to power say they feel abandoned and want a change.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Bernie Sanders and Pope Francis Meet Briefly at the Vatican
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders leaving the Vatican on Saturday. He was at the Vatican for a conference on social and economic issues.
item.description: The brief meeting took place at the Vatican on Saturday morning before the pontiff left for Greece, the senator said.
item.dc:creator: YAMICHE ALCINDOR and JIM YARDLEY

item.title: Pope Francis Takes 12 Refugees Back to Vatican After Trip to Greece
item.media:description: Pope Francis arriving Saturday at the Moria detention center on the Greek island of Lesbos, where refugees are held as they await rulings on their asylum applications.
item.description: The pontiff visited Lesbos, the heart of Europe’s migrant crisis, asking for deeper sympathy at a moment when attitudes are hardening.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Second Powerful Earthquake Strikes Japan
item.description: After nine people were killed in an earthquake on Thursday on the island of Kyushu, a more powerful temblor struck the same area, killing at least 23.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Criticizing Israel, Bernie Sanders Highlights Split Among Jewish Democrats
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Sanders at Thursday night’s Democratic debate in Brooklyn. In response to a question about Israel, Mr. Sanders said that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu “is not right all of the time.”
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Sanders’s comments at Thursday’s Democratic debate buoyed critics of Benjamin Netanyahu’s government but worried pro-Israel Jewish groups.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Critic of Psychologists’ Role in Interrogation Is Asked to Reconsider
item.description: David Hoffman, a Chicago lawyer, found that a number of psychologists had shielded America’s interrogation techniques.
item.dc:creator: JAMES RISEN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Path of $681 Million: From Saudi Arabia to Malaysian Premier’s Personal Account
item.media:description: Adel al-Jubeir, the Saudi foreign minister, arrived at a security conference in Munich in February.
item.description: Despite assurances from Malaysian and Saudi officials, suspicions persist surrounding the $681 million that was deposited into Najib Razak’s bank account last year.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Phil Sayer, Voice Behind ‘Please Mind the Gap’ on London Underground, Dies at 62
item.media:description: Phil Sayer in 2014. His was not the only voice cautioning passengers to “mind the gap,” but it is arguably the most familiar one.
item.description: Mr. Sayer, an English voice actor, first recorded messages for the London Underground in 2005. “Mind the gap” has been in use since 1969.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Kremlin Apologizes to German Newspaper for Wrongly Tying It to Goldman Sachs
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia arriving to speak with journalists after his annual live call-in show in Moscow on Thursday.
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin misspoke when he said Süddeutsche Zeitung, which published reports about the Panama Papers, was owned by Goldman Sachs.
item.dc:creator: OLEG MATSNEV

item.title: As China’s Growth Slows, Banks Feel the Strain of Bad Debt
item.media:description: A construction site in Beijing on Friday. China’s total local-currency loans have more than tripled since the start of 2009.
item.description: Chinese lenders feel rising pain from souring loans in troubled industries — even as they face pressure to keep local companies afloat.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Artist Nurtures a Creative Oasis in Conservative Saudi Arabia
item.media:description: “I saw how people listened without thinking, like a flock of sheep.” ABDULNASSER GHAREM
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: Abdulnasser Gharem has taken artistic aim at what he sees as the kingdom’s byzantine bureaucracy, religious dogmatism and dependence on oil.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: Saudi Arabia Moves to Curb Its Feared Religious Police
item.media:description: Saudi women attending the Amex Luxury Expo in Ryadh, Saudi Arabia, on April 2.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The kingdom announced steps to overhaul the force, saying members could no longer detain or pursue suspects, and should be “gentle and kind,” rather than heavy-handed.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: E.U.’s Five Biggest Economies Join Tax Crackdown After Panama Papers
item.media:description: George Osborne, the British chancellor of the Exchequer, said the agreement demonstrated that “no single country can tackle international tax evasion alone.”
item.description: Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Spain have agreed to share information on company ownership and that urged the Group of 20 Nations to do the same.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Chinese General Visits Disputed Spratly Islands in South China Sea
item.media:description: Chinese soldiers on the Spratly Islands, known in China as the Nansha Islands, in February. The sign at the right reads, “Nansha is our national land, sacred and inviolable.”
item.description: Although the details of the trip were sparse, it appeared intended to show China’s determination to ward off any challenges to its claims over the islands.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Taiwan Fears Fraud Suspects in Malaysia May Be Deported to China
item.media:description: Chinese and Taiwanese suspected of being involved in wire fraud, in center seats, arriving at Beijing Capital International Airport on Wednesday.
item.media:credit: Yin Gang/Xinhua News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Legislators in Taiwan warned that dozens of its people could be sent from Malaysia to mainland China, echoing a similar incident involving Kenya.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: News Analysis: In South China Sea Visit, U.S. Defense Chief Flexes Military Muscle
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter attended the closing ceremony of a joint United States-Philippine military exercise in Quezon City, Philippines, on Friday.
item.description: Ashton B. Carter’s tour sent a message that Americans would work with allies to counter Beijing’s expanding presence, but China may feel a need to speed up its own military buildup.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Spanish Castle’s Restoration, Called ‘Disaster’ by Some, Wins Prize
item.media:description: The restoration of the Matrera Castle in southern Spain has drawn comparisons to a botched amateur restoration in 2012 of a nearly century-old fresco of Jesus in the county’s northeast.
item.description: The award, from Architizer, is a vindication of sorts for the architect Carlos Quevedo Rojas, who reinforced stone battlements with a wall of mortar.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Belgium’s Transportation Minister Resigns Amid Outcry
item.media:description: The transportation minister of Belgium, Jacqueline Galant, in Brussels on Thursday. She came under heavy criticism this week, with opposition lawmakers demanding that she go.
item.description: Jacqueline Galant stepped down after the publication of leaked reports warning of security deficiencies at Brussels Airport, which was bombed on March 22.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Spain’s Industry Minister Steps Down Over Panama Papers Revelations
item.media:description: José Manuel Soria, the Spanish minister of industry, energy and tourism, in Parliament on Wednesday. His name appeared in the Panama Papers.
item.description: The resignation of José Manuel Soria, who has not been charged with wrongdoing, comes at a time of turmoil in Spanish politics, after inconclusive elections in December.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: At U.N., Ambassadors Hold Auditions for Next Secretary General
item.description: He or she will face daunting challenges, from stopping wars, to holding peacekeepers accountable for rape, to nudging governments to tackle climate change.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Documentary Stirs French as Officials Weigh a Labor Overhaul
item.media:description: François Ruffin, the “Merci Patron!” director, in Paris.
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: François Ruffin’s film “Merci Patron!” takes on the luxury giant LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton and its chief executive, Bernard Arnault.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.category: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA

item.title: Gunmen Kill Scores of Civilians in Western Ethiopia, Official Says
item.description: The attackers came from South Sudan and killed 140 civilians, including women and children, Ethiopia’s communications minister said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Opinion: Syria’s Future: A Black Hole of Instability
item.media:description: Kobani, Syria. Wednesday, October 28, 2015
item.description: Peace talks have restarted, but Bashar al-Assad and the rebels are fighting over a state that is beyond salvaging.
item.dc:creator: THANASSIS CAMBANIS

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The End of Catholic Guilt
item.description: Pope Francis is merely acknowledging the obvious. As before, he’s using words to change hearts.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY EGAN

item.title: Editorial Observer: In Paris, a Protest Movement Awakens
item.media:description: Protesters gathered at Place de La Republique in Paris on Tuesday.
item.description: Students are rising up against the existing political and economic order.
item.dc:creator: MIRA KAMDAR

item.title: Feature: The New Europeans
item.media:description: The Mzayek family outside a shelter in Eisenärzt.
item.media:credit: Hellen van Meene for The New York Times
item.description: As refugees stream into Europe, and terror attacks spark security fears, one Bavarian village grapples with newcomers — and with the question of what it means to be German.
item.dc:creator: JAMES ANGELOS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Victims of the Brussels Attacks
item.description: Thirty-five victims from at least eight countries were killed in the attacks. Here are profiles of some of the victims, updated as more names are confirmed.

item.title: How ISIS Built the Machinery of Terror Under Europe’s Gaze
item.media:description: The Paris attacks left 130 dead in November, but a branch within the Islamic State was obsessed with striking Europe at least two years before then.
item.description: Two years before the Paris and Brussels assaults, a special branch of the group was churning out smaller attacks that the authorities repeatedly discounted as isolated or random acts.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
